p.seg: TWENTY FOURTH ANNUAL REPORT OF THE SECRETARY OF THE STATE BANKING BOARD SHOWING THE CONDITION OF THE Building and Loan Associations OF NEBRASKA FOR THE YEAR ENDING JUNE 30, 1916 SUBMITTED TO THE GOVERNOR AND THE 8TATE BANKING BOARD SEPTEMBER 1, 1916 1916 ■• By E. ROYSE, Secretary

DEPARTMENT OF BANKING OF THE STATE OF NEBRASKA BOARD HON. JOHN H. MOREHEAD Governor, President HON. W. H. SMITH Auditor of Public Accounts HON. WILLIS E. REED...- Attorney General E. ROYSE." _.._ _ - _ - Secretary JOSEPH V. JOHNSON Clerk MAUDE HOGE - - Assistant Clerk ANNA GASS __ Assistant Clerk TILLIE C. EPPENS Stenographer EXAMINERS S. M. PATTERSON M. C. WILDE E. E. EMMETT S. A. LAPP E. N. VAN HORNE T. R. RILEY A. D. TOUZALIN JOHN BOATSMAN J. H. DONNELLY

State of Nebraska, Department of Banking, Lincoln, September 1, 1916. To the Honorables John H. Morehead, Governor; William H. Smith, Auditor of Public Accounts ; Willis E. Reed, Attor- ney General, Members of the State Banking Board, Gentlemen : I beg to hand you herewith the Twenty-fourth Annual Report of the Department of Banking, showing the condition of the building and loan associations of the State of Nebraska at the close of the fiscal year June 30, 1916, compiled from annual reports of these associations, which contains tabulated statements, detailed reports, with other information and com - ments, so that the true condition of these associations may be known and comparisons made with reports submitted in previous years to your honorable body. I am pleased to report the steady growth and expansion of these associations, the resources having increased $6,256,976.55, and to supplement this statement with the in - formation that as a rule these institutions are capably man - aged, and deserve the confidence of the people of their com - munities. However, as in my previous report, I must voice my conclusion that there is an over optimism, and not that degree of prudence in loaning, as is clearly demonstrated by the amount of loans in foreclosure and subject to foreclosure, which approximates a total of $1,000,000.00, with an addi - tional $1,000,000.00 or more in other real estate and real estate sold on contract, making a grand total of over $2,000,000.00. I called your attention to this matter in the report of 1915, but again desire to emphasize the significance of this item as a part of the general summary given. I would not feel that my duty had been fully done did I not call attention to the apparent excessive rate of interest charged borrowers as shown from year to year in the statistics of these associations, and pursuant to this policy I am directing your special attention to the rate of dividends declared on running stock and on full paid or matured stock, and the rate of interest charged borrowers during the year, to which must be added premiums charged borrowers. The average per cent of dividends declared on running stock is seven and seven-tenths per cent, full paid or matured stock is six per cent; the rate of interest charged

SECRETARY OF THE STATE BANKING BOARD 5 borrowers averaged eight and two-tenths per cent, together with the additional two and five-tenths per cent premium, making a total average of ten and seven-tenths per cent paid by borrowing members during the year. While it is true that the borrowing member receives some benefit by way of reduction of his rate in the dividends paid or credited on the amount he has paid in on his stock, yet the fact remains and is clearly apparent that in many building and loan associations he is penalized by a too high rate of interest. I am of the opinion that the time is not far distant when legislative interference will be necessary in the adjustment of this matter in the fixing by legal enactment, or the conferring of authority upon some body, to fix a maximum and lower rate of interest, especially on full paid and matured stock. The Department can not see any justice in the home builder (in whose interests these associations are supposed to be created) being taxed to pay a higher rate of interest to that portion of the investing public which seeks the advantage of the high rates of interest now prevalent paid by these asso - ciations. These are the two prominent items in this report to which I feel it my duty to direct your attention, viz: The indiscreet loaning made manifest by the number of mort - gages in foreclosure and subject to foreclosure, and the rates paid by borrowers, as shown heretofore. It must be clear to anyone conversant with the financial conditions as they now exist, that a period of falling prices and lower price levels will mean serious results for building and loan associations that do not trim their sails for what will eventually come as a sequel to present over optimism. Very respectfully, E. ROYSE, Secretary State Banking Board.
